article.title: Cerberus
article.paragraph: Aboutthe mythical dogUse dmy datesJune 2013File:Herakles Kerberos Eurystheus Louvre E701.jpgthumbrightHeraclespresenting Cerberus to a frightenedEurystheushiding in a pot.Etruscan civilizationEtruscanhydria(c. 530 BC) fromCaere(Louvre E701).Ogden 2013a, p. 105; Gantz, p. 22;LIMCHerakles 2616; PerseusLouvre E 701 (Vase).InGreek mythology,Cerberus(IPAc-enˈsɜrbərəs;cite webhttp://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/CerberusCerberusMerriam-Webster Online Dictionary[[Merriam-Webster]]2009-07-16lang-grc-greΚέρβεροςKerberosIPA-elˈkerberos), often called the "hound of Hades", is a monstrouspolycephalymulti-headeddog, who guards the gates of theunderworld, preventing the dead from leaving. He was the offspring of the monstersEchidna (mythology)EchidnaandTyphon, and is usually described as having three heads, a serpent for a tail, with snakes protruding from various parts of his body. Cerberus is primarily known for his capture byHeracles, one of Heracles'Labours of Herculestwelve labours.
article.heading: Descriptions
article.paragraph: File:Herakles Kerberos Louvre F204.jpgthumbHeracles and a two-headed Cerberus with a snake protruding from each head and a snake tail.Etruscan civilizationEtruscanamphora(c. 550–500 BC) fromVulci(Louvre F204)Beazley Archive200011; PerseusLouvre F 204 (Vase).Descriptions of Cerberus vary, including the number of his heads. Cerberus was usually three-headed, though not always. Cerberus had a multi-headed heritage. His father was the multi snake-headedTyphon,Hesiod,Theogony300–314,Acusilaus, fragment 6 (Freeman,p. 15),Hyginus,FabulaePreface,151, andQuintus Smyrnaeus,Posthomerica(orFall of Troy)6.260–268 (pp. 272–275)all have Cerberus as the offspring of Typhon and Echidna, whileBacchylides, Ode5.56–62,Sophocles,Women of Trachis1097–1099,Callimachus, fragment 515 Pfeiffer (Trypanis,pp. 258–259), andOvid,Metamorphoses4.500–501,7.406–409all have Cerberus as the offspring of Echidna without naming a father.and Cerberus was the brother of three other multi-headed monsters, the multi-snake-headedLernaean Hydra;Orthrus, the two-headed dog who guarded the Cattle ofGeryon; and theChimera (mythology)Chimera, who had three heads, that of a lion, a goat, and a snake.Hesiod,Theogony309–324(although it is not certain whom Hesiod meant as the mother of the Chimera: Echidna, the Hydra, or Ceto);Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)Apollodorus,2.5.10,2.3.1;Hyginus,FabulaePreface.And, like these close relatives, Cerberus was, with only the rare iconographic exception, multi-headed.

In the earliest description of Cerberus,Hesiod'sTheogony(c. 8th 7th century BC), Cerberus has fifty heads, whilePindar(c. 522 c. 443 BC) gave him one hundred heads.Gantz p. 22; Ogden 2013a, p. 105, with n. 182;Hesiod,Theogony311–312;Pindar, fragment F249a/b SM, from a lost Pindar poem on Heracles in the underworld, according to a scholia on theIliad.However, later writers almost universally give Cerberus three heads.Ogden 2013a, pp. 105–106, with n. 183;Sophocles,Women of Trachis22–25("three-bodied"),1097–1099;Euripides,Heracles (Euripides)Heracles610–611,1276–1278;Virgil,Aeneid6.417–421("triple-throated", "three fierce mouths"),Georgics4.483("triple jaws");Ovid,Metamorphoses4.449–451("three-visaged mouths", "triple-barking");Seneca the YoungerSeneca,Agamemnon859–862 (pp. 198–199)("triple chains"),Hercules Furens60–62 (pp. 52–53)("triple necks"),782–784 (pp. 110–111);Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)Apollodorus,2.5.12.An exception is the Latin poetHorace's Cerberus which has a single dog head, and one hundred snake heads.West,p. 108; Ogden 2013a, p. 107;Horace,Odes3.11.17–20 (West,pp. 101–103) ("a hundred snakes ... triple-tongued"),Odes2.13.33–36("hundred-headed"),Odes2.19.29–32("triple tongue").

In art Cerberus is most commonly depicted with two heads (visible), never more than three, and occasionally only one.Gantz, p. 22; Ogden 2013a, p. 106. According to Gantz, "Presumably the frequent variant of two heads arose from logistical problems in draftmanship," and Ogden wonders if "such images salute or establish a tradition of a two-headed Cerberus, or are we to imagine a third head concealed behind the two that can be seen?"On one of his two earliest depictions (c. 590–580 BC), a cup fromArgos, now lost, Cerberus is shown as a normal single-headed dog.Gantz, p. 22; Ogden 2013a, p. 106, with n. 184 (which also mentions a reliefpithosfragment (c. 590–570) which seems to show a single lion-headed Cerberus);LIMCHerakles 2553.The first appearance of a three-headed Cerberus occurs on a mid sixth century BC cup fromLaconia.Gantz, p. 22; Ogden 2013a, p. 106, with n. 185;LIMCHerakles 2605.

Horace's many snake-headed Cerberus followed a long tradition of Cerberus being part snake. This is perhaps already implied as early as Hesiod, with his mother being the half-snakeEchidna (mythology)Echidna, and his father the snake-headed Typhon. The lost Argos cup shows snakes protruding from Cerberus' body, while the mid sixth-century BC Laconian cup gives Cerberus a snake tail. In the literary record, the first certain indication of Cerberus' serpentine nature comes from the rationalized account ofHecataeus of Miletus(fl. 500–494 BC), who makes Cerberus a large poisonous snake.Hecataeus of Miletus,FGrH1 F27 (apudPausanias (geographer)Pausanias,3.25.5); Ogden 2013a, p. 107.Platorefers to Cerberus' composite nature,PlatoRepublic588c.andEuphorion of Chalcis(3rd century BC) describes Cerberus as having multiple snake tails, and presumably in connection to his serpentine nature, associates Cerberus with the creation of the poisonousAcontiumaconiteplant.Euphorian, fragment 71 Lightfoot (Lightfoot,pp. 300–303); Ogden 2013b,pp. 69–70; Ogden 2013a, p. 107.Virgilhas snakes writhe around Cerberus' neck,Virgil,Aeneid6.419,Ovid's Cerberus has a venomous mouth,Ovid,Metamorphoses4.500–501.whileSeneca the YoungerSenecagives Cerberus a mane consisting of snakes, and a single snake tail.Seneca the YoungerSeneca,Hercules Furens785–812 (pp. 112–113). See alsoLucan,Pharsalia6.664–665, which has Cerberus' heads "bristling" with snakes; andBibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)Apollodorus,2.5.12whose Cerberus is snake-tailed and has "on his back the heads of all sorts of snakes".

Cerberus was given various other traits. According toEuripides, Cerberus not only had three heads but three bodies,EuripidesHeracles (Euripides)Heracles22–25.and according to Virgil he had multiple backs.Virgil,Aeneid6.422.Cerberus ate raw flesh (according to Hesiod),Hesiod,Theogony311.had eyes which flashed fire (according to Euphorion), a three-tongued mouth (according to Horace) and acute hearing (according to Seneca).Seneca the YoungerSeneca,Hercules Furens788–791 (pp. 112–113).
article.heading: The Twelfth Labour of Heracles

link.target: File:12th labour of Heracles - Project Gutenberg eText 19119.png
link.part: Athena, Hermes and Heracles, leading a two-headed Cerberus out of Hades, as Persephone looks on. From ahydria(c. 550–500 BC) attributed to theLeagros Group(Louvre CA 2992).LIMCHerakles 2599ad; Beazley Archive302005. Reproduced from Baumeister'sDenkmler des klassichen Alterthums,volume I., figure 730 (text on p. 663).

article.paragraph: As early asHomerwe learn that Heracles was sent byEurystheus, the king ofTiryns, to bring back Cerberus fromHades.Homer,Iliad8.367–368; compare withOdyssey11.620–626. Heracles is also given the task by Eurystheus inHecataeus of Miletus,FGrH1 F27 (apudPausanias (geographer)Pausanias,3.25.5),Euripides,Heracles (Euripides)Heracles1276–1278,PirithousTrGF43 F1 lines 10–14 (Ogden 2013b,p. 70; Collard and Cropp,pp. 646–647);Euphorion of Chalcis, fragment 71 Lightfoot (Lightfoot,pp. 300–303);Diodorus Siculus,4.25.1;Hyginus,Fabulae32.According toBibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)Apollodorus, this was the twelfth and final labour imposed on Heracles.Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)Apollodorus,2.5.12. So also in Euphorion, fragment 71 Lightfoot 13 (Lightfoot,pp. 302–303), andJohn TzetzesTzetzes,Chiliades2.36.388–389 (Greek: Kiessling,pp. 55–56; English translation: Berkowitz,p. 33).Euripides,Heracles (Euripides)Heracles22–25, calls this labor the last. However according toDiodorus Siculus,4.25.2this labor was the eleventh and next to last, the twelfth being theApples of the Hesperides.In a fragment from a lost playPirithous, (attributed to eitherEuripidesor his contemporaryCritias) Heracles says that, although Eurystheus commanded him to bring back Cerberus, it was not from any desire to see Cerberus, but only because Eurystheus thought that the task was impossible.PirthousTrGF43 F1 lines 10–14 (Ogden 2013b,p. 70; Collard and Cropp,pp. 646–647); Ogden 2013a, p. 113.

Heracles was aided in his mission by his being an initiate of theEleusinian Mysteries. Euripides has his initiation being "lucky" for Heracles in capturing Cerberus.EuripidesHeracles (Euripides)Heracles612–613; Papadopoulou,p. 163.And bothDiodorus Siculusand Apollodorus say that Heracles was initiated into the Mysteries, in preparation for his descent into the underworld. According to Diodorus, Heracles went to Athens, whereMusaeus of AthensMusaeus, the son ofOrpheus, was in charge of the initiation rites,Diodorus Siculus,4.25.1–2.while according to Apollodorus, he went toEumolpusatEleusis.Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)Apollodorus,2.5.12, which adds that, since it was unlawful for foreigners to be initiated, Heracles was adopted by Pylius, and that before Heracles could be inititated, he first had to be "cleansed of the slaughter of the centaurs"; see also Frazer, n. 2.

Heracles also had the help ofAthenaandHermes. In theOdyssey, Homer has Athena and Hermes as his guides.Homer,Odyssey11.620–626; compare withPausanias (geographer)Pausanias,8.18.3.Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)Apollodorus,2.5.1also has Hermes aiding Heracles in the underworld.And Athena and Hermes, are often shown with Heracles on vase paintings depicting Cerberus' capture.Examples include: Boston 28.46 (LIMCHerakles 2556, Beazley Archive302270), BM 1893.7-12.11 (LIMCHerakles 2603, Beazley Archive302997), Edinburg 1881.44.27 (LIMCHerakles 2581, Beazley Archive301604), Louvre A481 (Beazley Archive10772), CA 2992 (LIMCHerakles 2599ad, Beazley Archive302005), Met 06.1021.78 (LIMCHerakles 2587ad, Beazley Archive3764), Munich 2306 (LIMCHerakles 2602, Beazley Archive202086), Toledo 1950.261 (LIMCHerakles 2593, Beazley Archive701), 1969.371 (LIMCHerakles 2599, Beazley Archive701), Vatican 372 (LIMCHerakles 2561, Beazley Archive302102).By most accounts, Heracles made his descent into the underworld through an entrance atTainaron. The place is first mentioned in connection with the Cerberus story in the rationalized account ofHecataeus of Miletus(fl. 500494 BC), and Euripides,Seneca the YoungerSeneca, and Apolodorus, all have Heracles descend into the underworld there.Hecataeus of Miletus,FGrH1 F27 (apudPausanias (geographer)Pausanias,3.25.5);Euripides,Heracles (Euripides)Heracles22–25;Seneca the YoungerSeneca,Hercules Furens662–696 (pp. 102–105);Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)Apollodorus,2.5.1.HoweverXenophonreports that Heracles was said to have descended atHeraclea Pontica, a place more usually associated with Heracles' exit from the underworld (see below).Xenophon of Athens,Anabasis (Xenophon)Anabasis6.2.2.Heraclea, founded c. 560 BC, perhaps took its name from the association of its site with Heracles' Cerberian exploit.Ogden 2013a, p. 108.
article.heading: Theseus and Pirithous
article.paragraph: While in the underworld, Heracles met the heroesTheseusandPirithous, where the two companions were being held prisoner by Hades for attempting to carry offPersephone, and, along with bringing back Cerberus, Heracles also managed (usually) to rescue Theseus, and in some versions Pirithous as well.Gantz, pp. 291–295.According to Apollodorus, Heracles found Theseus and Pirithous near the gates of Hades, bound to the "Chair of Forgetfulness, to which they grew and were held fast by coils of serpents", and when they saw Heracles, "they stretched out their hands as if they should be raised from the dead by his might", and Heracles was able to free Theseus, but when he tried to raise up Pirithous, "the earth quaked and he let go."Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)Apollodorus,2.5.12,E.1.24.

The earliest evidence for the involvement of Theseus and Pirithous in the Cerberus story, is found on a shield-band relief (c. 560 BC) fromOlympia, GreeceOlympia, where Theseus and Pirithous (named) are seated together on a chair, arms held out in supplication, while Heracles approaches, about to draw his sword.LIMCHerakles 3519; Gantz, p. 292.The earliest literary mention of the rescue occurs in Euripides, where Heracles saves Theseus (with no mention of Pirithous).EuripidesHeracles (Euripides)Heracles1169–1170.; Gantz, p. 293.In the lost playPirithous, both heroes are rescued,Gantz, P. 293; Collard and Cropp,pp. 637;PirithousTrGF43 F1 Hypothesis (Collard and Cropp,pp. 640–641).while in the rationalized account ofPhilochorus, Heracles was able to rescue Theseus, but not Pirithous.Philochorus,FGrH328 F18b (Ogden 2013b,p. 73); Ogden 2013a, p. 109. Compare withPlutarch,Theseus35.1.In one place Diodorus says Heracles brought back bothTheseusandPirithous, by the favor of Persephone,Diodorus Siculus,4.26.1.while in another he says that Pirithous remained in Hades, or according to "some writers of myth" that neither Theseus, nor Pirithous returned.Diodorus Siculus,4.63.4; Gantz, pp. 294–295.Both are rescued in Hyginus.Hyginus,Fabulae79.
article.heading: Capture of Cerberus
article.paragraph: There are various versions of how Heracles accomplished Cerberus' capture. According to Apollodorus, Heracles asked Hades for Cerberus, and Hades told Heracles he would allow him to take Cerberus only if he "mastered him without the use of the weapons which he carried", and so, using his lion-skin as shield, Heracles squeezed Cerberus around the head until he submitted.Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)Apollodorus,2.5.1.

In two early sources Cerberus' capture seems to involve Heracles fighting Hades. Homer has Hades injured by an arrow shot by Heracles,Homer,Iliad5.395–397.while on the early sixth-century BC lost Argos cup, Heracles is shown attacking Hades with a stone.Ogden 2013a, p. 111. Compare with Seneca,Hercules Furens48–51 (pp. 52–53), where Heracles brings back "spoils of triumph over that conquered king ... subdued Dis".A scholium to theIliadpassage, explains that Hades had commanded that Heracles "master Cerberus without shield or Iron". Heracles did this, by (as in Apollodorus) using his lion-skin instead of his shield, and making stone points for his arrows, but when Hades still opposed him, Heracles shot Hades in anger.Schol.HomerIliad5.395–397 (Ogden 2013b,p. 66); Ogden 2013a, p. 112.Consistent with the no iron requirement, the iconographic tradition, from c. 560 BC, often shows Heracles using his wooden club against Cerberus.Ogden 2013a, p. 111.

Euripides, has Amphitryon ask Heracles: "Did you conquer him in fight, or receive him from the goddess [i.e. Persephone]? To which, Heracles answers: "In fight",EuripidesHeracles (Euripides)Heracles610–613. This question is echoed in Seneca,Hercules Furens760–761 (pp. 110–111), where Amphitryon asks "Is it spoil [Heracles] brings, or a willing gift from his uncle.and thePirithousfragment says that Heracles "overcame the beast by force".PirithousTrGF43 F1 Hypothesis (Collard and Cropp,pp. 640–641).However, according to Diodorus, Persphone welcomed Heracles "like a brother" and gave Cerberus "in chains" to Heracles.Aristophanes, has Heracles gag and seize Cerberus, then run off,Aristophanes,Frogs465–469.while Seneca has Heracles again use his lion-skin as shield, and his wooden club, to subdue Cerberus, after which a quailing Hades and Persephone, allow Heracles to lead a chained and submissive Cerberus away.Seneca the YoungerSeneca,Hercules Furens797–812 (pp. 112–113).Cerberus is often shown being chained, and Ovid tells that Heracles dragged Cerberus with chains ofadamant.Ovid,Metamorphoses7.409–413.
article.heading: Exit from the underworld
article.paragraph: There were several locations which were said to be the place where Heracles brought up Cerberus from the underworld. Seneca has Heracles return with Cerberus at Tainaron, the same place he had entered.Seneca the YoungerSeneca,Hercules Furens663 (pp. 102–105)(entrance),813 (pp. 112–113)(exit). Seneca's account may reflect a much older tradition rationalized byHecataeus of Miletus,FGrH1 F27 (apudPausanias (geographer)Pausanias,3.25.5), see Ogden 2013a, p. 112.Apollodorus, who has Heracles descend at Tainaron, has him exit atTroezen.Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)Apollodorus,2.5.12.The geographerPausanias (geographer)Pausaniastells us that there was a temple at Troezen with "altars to the gods said to rule under the earth", where it was said that, in addition to Cerberus being "dragged" up by Heracles,Semelewas supposed to have been been brought up out of the underworld byDionysus.Pausanias (geographer)Pausanias,2.31.2. See alsoJohn TzetzesTzetzes,Chiliades2.36.404 (Greek: Kiessling,pp. 55–56; English translation: Berkowitz,p. 33), which has Cerberus brought up at Troezen.

Euphorion has Cerberus brought up atHeraclea Pontica,Euphorion of ChalcisEuphorion, fragment 41 Lightfoot (Lightfoot,pp. 272–275).the same place which Xenophon had earlier associated with Heracles' descent. And Euphorion and Ovid make Cerberus the cause of the poisonous plantAconitumaconite, which grew in abundance atHeraclea Pontica. According to Euphorion, when Heracles brought Cerberus up from the underworld, Cerberus "vomited gall" from which theAconitumaconiteplant grew up,Euphorion of ChalcisEuphorion, fragment 41a Lightfoot (Lightfoot,pp. 272–275); Ogden 2013a, pp. 107–108.while according to Ovid, upon leaving the underworld, as Cerberus was being dragged by Heracles from a cave, dazzled by the unaccustomed daylight, Cerberus spewed out a "poison-foam", which made the aconite plants growing there poisonous.Ovid,Metamorphoses7.413–419.Seneca's Cerberus too, like Ovid's, reacts violently to his first sight of daylight. Enraged, the previously submissive Cerberus struggles furiously, and Heracles and Theseus must together drag Cerberus into the light.Seneca the YoungerSeneca,Hercules Furens797–821 (pp. 112–115); see alsoAgamemnon,859–862 (pp. 198–199), which has Cerberus "fearing the colour of the unknown light."

Pausanias reports that according to local legend Cerberus was brought up through a chasm in the earth dedicated to Clymenus (Hades) next to the sanctuary ofChthoniaatErmioniHermione, and in Euripides'Heracles, thought Euripides does not say that Cerberus was brought out there, he has Cerberus kept for a while in the "grove ofChthonia" at Hermione.Pausanias (geographer)Pausanias,2.35.10;Euripides,Heracles (Euripides)Heracles615.Pausanias also mentions that at Mount Laphystion in Boeotia, that there was a statue of HeraclesCharops (mythology)Charops("with bright eyes"), where the Boeotians said Heracles brought up Cerberus.Pausanias (geographer)Pausanias,9.34.5.
Other locations which perhaps were also associated with Cerberus being brought out of the underworld include,Hierapolis,Thesprotia, and Emeia nearMycenae.Ogden 2013a, pp. 112–113.
article.heading: Cerberus presented to Eurystheus, returned to Hades
article.paragraph: In some accounts, after bringing Cerberus up from the underworld, Heracles paraded the captured Cerberus through Greece. Euphorion, has Heracles lead Cerberus through Midea inArgolis, as women and children watch in fear,Euphorion, fragment 71 Lightfoot 14–15 (Lightfoot,pp. 302–303).andDiodorus Siculussays of Cerberus, that Heracles "carried him away to the amazement of all and exhibited him to men"while Seneca has Juno complain of Heracles "highhandedly parading the black hound through Argive cities."Seneca the YoungerSeneca,Hercules Furens46–62 (pp. 52–53).and has Heracles greeted by laurel-wreathed crowds, "singing" his praises.

Then, according to Apollodorus, Heracles showed Cerberus to Eurystheus, as commanded, after which he returned Cerberus to the underworld.However, accordingHesychius of Alexandria, Cerberus escaped, presumably returning to the underworld on his own.Hesychius of Alexandrias.v.''eleutheron hydor''(Ogden 2013b,pp. 69–70); Ogden 2013a, p. 114.
article.heading: In literature
article.paragraph: File:Cerbere.jpgthumbCerberus, as illustrated byGustave DorinDante's ''Divine Comedy''.Cerberus is featured in many prominent works of Greek and Roman literature, most famously inVirgil'sAeneid,Peisandros of Rhodes'epic poemtheLabours of Hercules, the story ofOrpheusinPlato'sSymposium, and inHomer'sIliad,Homer,Iliad8.367–368.which is the only known reference to one of Heracles' labours which first appeared in a literary source.citation neededSeptember 2015

Most occurrences in ancient literature revolve around the basis of the threat of Cerberus being overcome to allow a living being access to the underworld; in theAeneidCerberus was lulled to sleep after being tricked into eating drugged honeycakes and Orpheus put the creature to sleep with his music. InDante Alighieri'sInferno (Dante)Inferno, Canto VI, the "great worm" Cerberus is found in the Third Circle of Hell, where he oversees and rends to pieces those who have succumbed togluttony, one of theseven deadly sins.Dante.Divine ComedyInferno, canto VI

In theCerberus (constellation)constellation Cerberusintroduced byJohannes Heveliusin 1687, Cerberus is sometimes substituted for the "branch from the tree of the golden apples" fetched by Atlas from the garden of the Hesperides.cite webhttp://www.ianridpath.com/startales/cerberus.htmIan Ridpath, "Star Tales"Ianridpath.com2012-07-07
article.heading: In art
article.paragraph: Numerous references to Cerberus have appeared in ancientGreek artGreekandRoman art,Bloomfield,pp. 534–525found inarchaeologicalruins and often including in statues and architecture, inspired by the mythology of the creature. Cerberus' depiction in ancient art is not as definitive as in literature; the poets and linguists of ancient Greece and Rome mostly agreed on the physical appearance (with the notable exception mentioned above inHesiod'sTheogonyin which he had 50 heads). His depiction in classical art mostly shows the recurring motif of serpents, but the number of heads differs. A statue in theGalleria Borghesedepicts Cerberus with three heads sitting by the side of Hades, while a bronze sculpture depicting Heracles' twelfth labour shows the demi-god leading a two-headed Cerberus from the underworld. The majority of vases depicting the twelfth task also show Cerberus as having two heads. Classical critics have identified one of the earliest works of Cerberus as "the most imaginative," that being a Laconian vase created around 560 BC in which Cerberus is shown with three-heads and with rows of serpents covering his body and heads.cite bookA Companion to Classical MythologyRobertLenardonMarkMorfordMichaelShamOxford University Press19970-19-514725-1
article.heading: Etymology
article.paragraph:
File:RomanCerberus.JPGthumbrightDetail ofsculptureof godHadeswith CerberusThe name "Cerberus" is aLatinisedversion of the GreekKerberos. The etymology is uncertain. OgdenOgden 2013a, p. 105.refers to attempts to establish an Indo-European etymology as "not yet successful". It has been claimed to be related to theSanskritwordsarvar, used as an epithet of one of the dogs ofYama, from aProto-Indo-European languageProto-Indo-Europeanword *krberos, meaning "spotted".cite bookMallory J. P. J. P. Mallory Adams D. Q. Douglas Q. Adams
Chapter 25.10: Death and the Otherworld Oxford Introduction to Proto-Indo-European and the Proto-Indo-European World
Oxford, GBR Oxford University Press 2006 439 9780199287918 139999117 Lincoln (1991),Lincoln,pp. 96–97.among others, critiques this etymology. Lincoln notes a similarity between Cerberus and theNorse mythologyNorse mythologicaldogGarmr, relating both names to a Proto-Indo-European root*ger-"to growl" (perhaps with the suffixes-*m/*band-*r). However, as Ogden observes, this analysis actually requiresKerberosandGarmrto be derived from twodifferentIndo-European roots (*ker-and *gher-respectively), and so does not actually establish a relationship between the two names.

The use of a dog is uncertain,cite webhttp://www.etymonline.com/index.php?termCerberusOnline Etymology DictionaryDouglasHarper2008-10-21cite webhttp://colet.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/chuck/woodhouse_pages.pl?page_numWoodhouse's English-Greek DictionaryUniversity of Chicago Library2008-10-21although mythologists have speculated that the association was first made in the city of Trikarenos in Phliasia.Bloomfield,pp. 525–526.
article.heading: Explanations
article.paragraph: There have been many attempts to explain the depiction of Cerberus.A 2nd century CE Greek known asHeraclitus the paradoxographer- not to be confused with the 5th century BCE Greek philosopherHeraclitus- claimedEuhemerismeuhemeristicallythat Cerberus had two pups that were never away from their father, and that Cerberus was in fact a normal (though very large) dog, but that artists incorporating the two pups into their work made it appear as if his two children were in fact extra heads. Classical historians have dismissed Heraclitus the paradoxographer's explanation as "feeble". Mythologers have speculated that if Cerberus were given his name in Trikarenos it could be interpreted as "three karenos".
